vendor: Darena Solutions LLC dba Darena Health

access.description: The registered URL at www.darenasolutions.com 301-redirects to darena.health (domain rebrand), then the page at /meldrx-onc-hti1-certified performs a JavaScript redirect to /onc-hti1-certified. The final page is a Squarespace-hosted ONC certification page. The b(10) section is accessible via the #b10-EHI-Export-Documentation anchor — it scrolls directly to the section. A newsletter popup appears and must be dismissed. The section itself contains only two brief paragraphs about FHIR Bulk Export and DocumentReference, with no downloadable data dictionary. The linked swagger documentation at app.meldrx.com/swagger returns 404.

product_context.description: Darena Health (formerly MeldRx, BlueButtonPRO) is NOT an EHR — it is a FHIR middleware platform. It provides ONC-certified API modules as a SaaS service that EHR vendors integrate to achieve ONC certification compliance. Darena Health describes itself as 'the nation's first ONC Certified FHIR API.' The 11 products listed in CHPL are the actual EHR systems that use Darena Health as their certified module. These range widely: a hospital information system (Amrita HIS), specialty EHRs (ophthalmology — Doctorsoft, dermatology — EZDERM, behavioral health — PIMSY/Office Anywhere, physical therapy — Raintree), a radiology information system (eRAD RIS), a substance abuse treatment system (WITS), a public health system (Epi-Management), and full practice management suites with billing (Clinicmind, UnifiMD). Every one of these products stores substantial data beyond clinical documentation — billing/claims, scheduling, specialty-specific workflows, patient portals, document management, state reporting — that the underlying EHR databases contain but that Darena Health's FHIR middleware layer almost certainly does not have access to.
product_context.broader_product_name: Multiple products (Amrita HIS, Clinicmind, Doctorsoft, EZDERM, Epi-Management, Office Anywhere, PIMSY, Raintree, UnifiMD, WITS, eRAD RIS)

export_approach.description: Darena Health's EHI export is entirely FHIR-based. It uses two mechanisms: (1) FHIR Bulk Export for structured data, producing NDJSON files per the FHIR Bulk Data standard (STU 1.0.1), and (2) DocumentReference FHIR resources for non-FHIR content (which can wrap any file, including C-CDA documents). Because Darena Health is middleware — not the EHR itself — it can only export data that EHR vendors have pushed into its FHIR server. It has no direct access to the underlying EHR databases. This creates a fundamental architectural limitation: the export is bounded by whatever FHIR resources each vendor chose to map and send to Darena Health, not by what the EHR actually stores. This is the weakest possible export architecture for EHI completeness — the middleware cannot know what it doesn't have.

documentation_quality.description: The EHI export documentation is essentially nonexistent. The b(10) section on the certification page contains exactly two sentences describing the approach (FHIR Bulk Export + DocumentReference). There is no data dictionary, no list of FHIR resource types included in the export, no field-level documentation, no schema definitions, no sample data. The linked swagger documentation (app.meldrx.com/swagger) returns 404. The docs.darena.health site is a Postman-hosted API portal with general integration guidance, but it does not document what data is in the EHI export or what FHIR resources are supported for bulk export. A developer receiving an export would have no vendor-provided documentation to interpret the contents. They would need to rely entirely on generic FHIR R4 and US Core specifications.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: It is impossible to assess EHI coverage with confidence because there is no data dictionary and the export depends entirely on what each of the 11 EHR vendors feeds into the Darena Health FHIR server. At best, the export contains standard FHIR R4/US Core clinical resources (Patient, Condition, MedicationRequest, Observation, AllergyIntolerance, Procedure, Immunization, DiagnosticReport, etc.) plus DocumentReference wrappers for non-FHIR content like C-CDA documents. At worst, it contains only what was minimally needed for g(10) API certification. Given the middleware architecture, the export almost certainly does not include billing line items, insurance authorization details, scheduling data, patient-provider messages, specialty-specific data, or audit trails — data that every one of these 11 products stores but that would not typically be mapped to FHIR resources and pushed to a third-party middleware platform. The gap between what these products store and what this export likely contains is enormous.

clinical.evidence: The FHIR Bulk Export would include standard US Core clinical resources (Patient, Condition, MedicationRequest, Observation, AllergyIntolerance, Procedure, Immunization, etc.). Additionally, C-CDA documents wrapped in DocumentReference resources provide clinical summaries. However, specialty-specific clinical data (dermatology images, ophthalmology measurements, behavioral health assessments, PT functional outcomes, radiology workflows) would likely not be represented in standard FHIR resources.

secure_messages.evidence: No mention of messaging, inbox, communication, or portal messages anywhere in the documentation. Several of the underlying products (Clinicmind, Raintree, UnifiMD) have patient portals, but portal message data would not typically be sent to a FHIR middleware layer. FHIR Communication resources are not part of US Core and would require deliberate mapping.

billing_financial.evidence: No mention of billing, charges, claims, payments, or financial data anywhere in the documentation. Multiple underlying products (Clinicmind, Raintree, UnifiMD, PIMSY, eRAD) have extensive billing/RCM capabilities. FHIR has Claim/ExplanationOfBenefit resources but these are not part of US Core and billing data would not typically be pushed to a FHIR middleware layer. This is a critical gap given that billing data is part of the Designated Record Set.

insurance_coverage.evidence: No mention of insurance, coverage, eligibility, or authorization data. The underlying products handle insurance/payer data but this would remain in the EHR databases, not in the Darena Health FHIR server.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: No mention of appointments or scheduling. Multiple products (Clinicmind, Raintree, UnifiMD, PIMSY) have scheduling modules. FHIR Appointment resources exist but are not part of US Core and would not be in a typical FHIR Bulk Export from a middleware platform.

documents_images.evidence: The documentation explicitly mentions DocumentReference for non-FHIR resources, stating it 'can be used with any file, including CCDA.' This provides a mechanism for including documents, but whether each vendor actually maps their documents (scanned files, clinical photos, uploaded images, faxes) into DocumentReference resources in Darena Health is unknown and varies by vendor. Dermatology images (EZDERM), radiology images (eRAD), and scanned documents are unlikely to be pushed to the middleware layer.

audit_trails.evidence: No mention of audit logs, access tracking, or provenance in the EHI export documentation. Darena Health is certified for d(2) Auditable Events and d(3) Audit Reports, but these likely apply to access logs within the Darena Health platform itself, not to exporting audit trail data from the underlying EHR systems as part of the EHI export.

issues: The EHI export documentation consists of only two sentences — no data dictionary, no resource listing, no field definitions, no schema documentation whatsoever.
The linked swagger documentation at app.meldrx.com/swagger/index.html returns 404 Not Found, meaning the only referenced technical documentation is inaccessible.
Darena Health is FHIR middleware, not an EHR — it can only export data that EHR vendors push into it, creating a fundamental architectural limitation on export completeness.

11 diverse EHR products (hospital system, dermatology, ophthalmology, behavioral health, radiology, substance abuse treatment, practice management) all share the same two-sentence EHI export documentation, despite having vastly different data models and storage.

The FHIR Bulk Export approach is inherently limited for EHI completeness — standard FHIR R4 resources cannot represent billing line items, insurance authorizations, scheduling, patient portal messages, specialty-specific clinical data, or audit trails.
Products with extensive billing/RCM capabilities (Clinicmind, Raintree, UnifiMD, PIMSY, eRAD) almost certainly have billing data that is not included in the export.
Products with patient portals (Clinicmind, Raintree) likely have portal messaging data that is not included in the export.

Specialty-specific clinical data (dermatology images from EZDERM, ophthalmology measurements from Doctorsoft, behavioral health assessments from PIMSY/Office Anywhere, radiology workflows from eRAD) are unlikely to be captured in standard FHIR resources.
Substance abuse treatment data (WITS) and epidemiological surveillance data (Epi-Management) are highly specialized and almost entirely outside FHIR resource coverage.
The registered URL requires two redirects (domain rebrand + JavaScript redirect) to reach the actual content, reducing discoverability.

downloaded_files.description: Full ONC certification page containing the b(10) EHI Export Documentation section (two paragraphs describing FHIR Bulk Export + DocumentReference approach)
Postman-hosted API documentation portal for Darena Health. General integration guidance for developers; does not contain EHI export-specific documentation. Content is largely JavaScript-rendered.

summary: Darena Health is a FHIR middleware platform — not an EHR — that provides ONC-certified modules to 11 diverse EHR products ranging from hospital systems to dermatology to radiology to substance abuse treatment. The EHI export documentation is essentially nonexistent: two sentences describing FHIR Bulk Export and DocumentReference, with no data dictionary and dead swagger links. The middleware architecture means the export can only contain what each vendor pushes into the FHIR server, creating a fundamental gap between what these products actually store (billing, scheduling, messages, specialty data, images, audit trails) and what the export can provide. This is one of the weakest EHI export implementations encountered — inadequate documentation, architectural limitations preventing completeness, and a one-size-fits-all approach for 11 radically different products.
notes: The middleware certification model raises a systemic concern: Darena Health achieves b(10) certification, and then 11 EHR vendors claim compliance by integrating with it. But b(10) requires export of 'all EHI stored by the product of which the Health IT Module is a part.' If the certified module (Darena Health) is part of a product (e.g., Clinicmind), then the export must include ALL data from Clinicmind — including billing, scheduling, messages, etc. A FHIR middleware layer that only receives clinical FHIR resources from the EHR cannot satisfy this requirement. Each of the 11 products would need to ensure all their data is pushed to Darena Health, which is architecturally impractical. The ONC certification page mentions 'MeldRx is now Darena Health' — the company has rebranded at least twice (BlueButtonPRO → MeldRx → Darena Health).
